title: ✅ What Matters Most?
text:
Based on our findings, here’s what we know:

GPA is important, but not the sole deciding factor.
Test scores help, but students with lower scores can still get in.
Work experience adds value, but it’s not required.
Volunteer experience appears to have a strong positive impact.



If you were an admissions officer, here’s what you might consider: - Encourage holistic applications. Look beyond just numbers. - Consider balancing academic strength with extracurriculars. - Continue valuing diverse student backgrounds.



Admissions is more than just scores, it’s about the whole person. Future applicants should focus not just on grades, but also on gaining meaningful experiences.



Good luck!

title: Solving the College Admissions Puzzle
text:
Solving the College Admissions Puzzle
Each year thousands of students apply to universities, but only a select few get admitted. As the Dean of Admissions at a prestigious university, what makes them stand out to you? Are GPAs and test scores enough, or do other factors play a role?
To begin, let’s take a look at the big picture: who gets admitted and who doesn’t?




In the following sections, we will explore the factors that truly influence admissions and uncover unexpected insights that challenge common assumptions.

title: What Factors Drive Admissions?
text:
While a high GPA certainly helps, some students with lower GPAs were still accepted. Could other factors compensate?







Test scores are important but not everything. Some admitted students had mid-range scores, suggesting that a holistic approach is taken.







Students with some work experience tend to have a slight advantage. However, it’s not a strict requirement.







Higher volunteer involvement correlates with a higher acceptance rate, suggesting that universities value well-rounded applicants.

title: Findings
text:
GPA plays a crucial role in admissions. Higher GPAs generally lead to higher chances of acceptance.




The histogram above highlights the GPA distribution of applicants. We observe that most admitted students tend to have higher GPAs.

title: Findings
text:
Test scores also play a role but aren’t the sole determinant of admission.




While a higher test score helps, we notice that some students with mid-range scores were still admitted.

title: Findings
text:
Does having more work experience improve your chances?




The bar chart above suggests that students with some work experience are slightly more likely to be admitted, though it is not a strict requirement.

title: Findings
text:
Does giving back to the community improve admission chances?




This chart indicates that higher levels of volunteer involvement correlate with higher acceptance rates, suggesting that holistic applicants have an advantage.

title: Conclusion
text:
From our analysis, we found that the strongest applicants often have a high GPA, decent test scores, some work experience, and active volunteer involvement. However, there is no single formula for success—each applicant is evaluated holistically.



GPA: Higher GPA = Higher chance of admission.
Test Scores: Important, but not the sole factor.
Work Experience: Adds value but not mandatory.
Volunteer Work: Positively influences decisions.

title: Conclusion
text: Students looking to improve their admission chances should prioritize academic performance, gain relevant experience, and demonstrate community involvement.
